docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: At the core of the Senate debate on health care (front page, July 16) lies a profound moral issue: Should the United States remain the only modern industrial country that does not provide basic universal health coverage to its citizens? That is not even addressed in the current discussion.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of House Republicans, in defiance of their leaders, are trying to pass much tougher regulation of managed-care plans than the Senate adopted last week and say they can win if they can force a vote. House leaders, like the Republican-controlled Senate, are trying to stand firm against any legislation creating a right to sue health plans offered by most large, multistate employers. But dissidents talk openly of working with Democrats and passing a bill that would allow such suits while perhaps limiting the damages that could be awarded.

headline.main: Republican Rebels in the House Are Seeking to Pass a Tougher Bill on Managed Care

docs.lead_paragraph: LOCATION, location, location. It works in real estate and it works in health care. Finding a primary-care doctor in the South Norwalk area was a problem until about three months ago. Now, an average of 105 patients a day visit the new Norwalk Community Health Center on Water Street in downtown Norwalk.

headline.main: Handier Health Care for South Norwalk

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER listening to the rancorous debate in the Senate over health care reform last week, it would seem obvious that differences between Democrats and Republicans are profound. The Democrats wanted to give powerful new Federal rights to patients in managed-care plans. The Republicans countered with narrower regulations. The debate consisted largely of name-calling. Vice President Al Gore labeled the Republican plan a ''charade'' and Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, called it a fraud. Among the Republicans, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas accused the Democrats of deciding for political reasons ''to destroy H.M.O.'s.''

headline.main: The Nation; Beyond the Bluster Over Health Care

docs.abstract: Rancorous Senate debate over health care reform obscures fact that substantive differences are narrower than they seem and could be resolved if they were removed from partisan politics; photo; key areas of difference explained (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York. Senate 1. Medical Necessity: Vote on a Republican amendment to a Democratic patients' bill that would delete a provision granting doctors the right to decide what procedures are medically necessary and replace it with a provision that would leave the initial decision up to a doctor in the insurance company and allow patients to appeal if care is denied. Approved 52 to 48, July 13. 2. Patient Protection: Vote on an amendment to a Democratic patients' bill that would apply patient protections to all 161 Americans with private health insurance. Rejected 52 to 48, July 14.

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST how did Nassau County, one of the nation's wealthiest communities, manage to run up a record budget deficit during an economic boom? For one thing, not nearly enough prisoners have been forking over $150 a night for the privilege of lodging at the jail.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Insurance Ruling Could Raise Costs'' (front page, July 13): Since their inception, health maintenance organizations in New York State have been required to use community rates, meaning the same price for all members, regardless of age, sex, health or claims experience.
docs.abstract: Insurance Supt Neil D Levin letter on July 13 article says department's recent ruling was reminder to insurers in New York State that they must use same rates for all members, regardless of age, race, health or claims experience, unless they have approval for other rates; notes no HMO's have sought approval for alternative rates, but that some charge large groups inadquately low rates to gain market share at expense of small-group and individual subscribers

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite all the talk about protecting people in health maintenance organizations, most people in H.M.O.'s would gain no tangible benefit from many of the consumer-protection standards approved by the Senate this week as part of a bill to define patients' rights, lawyers and health policy experts said. Many of the bill's basic consumer protections would apply to 48 million people in group health plans regulated by the Federal Government. Few H.M.O.'s are in that category, according to data published recently in the journal Health Affairs.

headline.main: MOST IN H.M.O.'S WOULDN'T BENEFIT FROM SENATE BILL

docs.abstract: Lawyers and health policy experts say that despite all the talk about protecting people in health maintenance orgns, most people in HMO's would gain no tangible benefit from many of consumer-protection standards approved by Senate this week as part of bill to define patients' rights; many of bill's basic consumer protections would apply to 48 million people in group health plans regulated by Federal Government; few HMO's are in that category; most of 48 million people, it appears, get their health care through traditional fee-for-service arrangements or through loosely organized forms of managed care that are less restrictive than HMO's whose decisions about care have angered many consumers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: By the time the Senate's four-day debate over managed care ended on Thursday night, each party had won something. The Democrats had put the Republicans on record against some emotional health care proposals -- stands that they expect to highlight in the next campaign. The Republicans, for their part, passed a modest health care bill that they believe will shield them from attack next year. The ones likely to be left empty-handed were the American people. President Clinton's threat to veto anything resembling the Senate bill means there is little likelihood that any legislation on managed care will become law this year, unless the House takes an unexpected course.

headline.main: The Health Care Vote: Looking Ahead

docs.abstract: Senate approval of bill opposed by Pres Clinton makes it unlikely any managed health care bill will become law this year; debate over issue seems to be another example of stalemate gripping Congress; sparring was so intense that even measure on which everyone agreed could not win unanimous vote (M)
